node.title: Postprocessing: compute a residual like quantity with assembly

node.bodyText:
Hello
I think the easiest way to do this will be to use the tagging interface
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/framework_development/tagging.html
While computing your kernels, store this quantity in a tagged vector then it can be retrieved by the postprocessors system later
Guillaume

Dear Guillaume,
thank you for this hint. I got it running.
Cheers

node.title: #Include boost
node.bodyText:
Hello, I am trying to use some functions from the BOOST library and running into compile errors. When i try to #include the boost files from the library i get "file not found" errors, however when I put the source files directly into the src directory I get a ton of redefinition errors as boost is used in libmesh. Is there a better way to get the code to link against boost?
Thanks for your help.

This is the error message :
> school@b-mbp  ~/projects/dep   master ±  make -j 4

node.title: MOOSE website not working
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
MOOSE website has been down for a couple of hours now. Is anyone else having the same issues? Any ideas of when this can be resolved?
Many thanks,
Samin

Hello
We are aware of this, it's due to testing infrastructure migration. We are working with INL infrastructure to bring it back online. It should be back now or very soon
EDIT: should be working now
Guillaume
The migration was completed, and https://mooseframework.inl.gov/ is back online.
Hmmm, i still can't connect, and my PRs isn't testing properly either.  Do i have to do something special, eg, to activate the code coverage on PRs?  Other PRs, eg, #21699 , seem to work OK.

Looks like https://civet.inl.gov is down again, but was working earlier. So that's why the webhook governing the CI connection isn't working for PRs right now.
Tagging @loganharbour @milljm

When civet was down, the hook from GitHub that told it a PR was created/updated would not complete. This was unfortunately intentional as we were transitioning to a new server and we had to pause all writes to history on civet.
The easiest way to force a new hook for a PR is to rewrite history for the last commit:
git commit --amend --no-edit
git push --force

this will basically edit the last commit, changing its date to now. With “new” commits, a push will trigger a new event.
Thank you @loganharbour and @cticenhour .  I bet when i wake up tomorrow everything will be hunky dorey.
Still down. Wonder what happened... Ticket submitted.

node.title: PorousFlow - Simulation diverged
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I got a hydro-Mechanical simulation on PorousFlow that diverges even though the residuals are decreasing. As shown here
Time Step 2, time = 2.1, dt = 1.1
0 Nonlinear |R| = 9.898234e+06
0 Linear |R| = 9.898234e+06
1 Linear |R| = 7.617497e-09
1 Nonlinear |R| = 7.288478e+00
0 Linear |R| = 7.288478e+00
1 Linear |R| = 5.361864e-11
2 Nonlinear |R| = 3.644174e+00
0 Linear |R| = 3.644174e+00
1 Linear |R| = 1.679125e-11
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 2
Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge
I am coupling PorousFlow variables to several ODE Kernels. The poor convergence comes from there.
My preconditioner
[Preconditioning]
[lu]
type = SMP
full = true
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package'
petsc_options_value = ' lu       mumps'
[]
[]
thanks in advance!
Jose
Not sure if this will help. But in the executioner block try line_search = 'none' or line_search = 'bt' . I sometimes have problems with the default line_search option.

Thanks! line_search = 'none' worked. Also scaling reduce the initial residuals.
Cheers!
Jose

node.title: Non-contact grid on navier-stokes
node.bodyText:
Hi,
May I ask if MOOSE can complete the flow calculation on the non_contact grid? In fact, for heat conduction problem MOOSE can solve on the non-contact grid.

Thanks.

Hello
no we don’t. We re adding support for it right now, but we re doing a radiation interface not a convection interface.
You really should make a conforming mesh, it seems to me there is no reason not to here?
Guillaume

node.title: The pattern for face numbers for element and neighbor
node.bodyText:
Hello there. I have a question regarding the face numbers for element and neighbor. What pattern MOOSE/Libmesh uses to define _neighbor_side and _current_side?
From the HEX8 element, the local node numbers are defined in the documentation. However, I couldn't find how the faces are numbered and set for _neighbor_side and _current_side.
I have a 2 element model with an interface between them. The _current_side value is 2, and I expected the _neighbor_side to be 1, so  the two will be back to back and have opposite faces. But the _neighbor_side value is 4. What is the reason for this?
Thanks a lot,
Amir

Hello
I looked at the doxygen and the answer is here:
https://libmesh.github.io/doxygen/classlibMesh_1_1Hex8.html#ae6fd20a71114610dac6b527498248007
side 1 is made of nodes {0, 3, 2, 1},
side 2 of nodes  {0, 1, 5, 4},
etc
This is HEX8, it ll be different for each element type
Guillaume

node.title: Generator that combines node/element sets?
node.bodyText:
Hi all -
Is there a MeshGenerator that takes multiple node sets or element sets as input and combines them into a single, new set?

Hello
You can use the RenameBoundary and RenameBlock Generator to combine node / respectively element sets
Guillaume
Does that keep the old sets intact?

no.
why do you need to combine them?
we write most objects such that one can pass inputs like 'sideset1 sideset2' and it ll still work

I'm trying to read in Abaqus mesh files, which have this combining feature built-in, so I'm looking for an equivalent in MOOSE. I may be able to use your solution as long as individual node/element sets are not referred to.

node.title: MOOSE Framework Website Down
node.bodyText: Hello, I went to look at some syntax on the MOOSE Framework website and noticed that the entire website is down. Is there anyway to remedy this? Thanks.
mooseframework.inl.gov is available again.

node.title: A question about simulating a contracting ring
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I want to simulate a contracting ring by increasing its inner radius but not changing its outer radius, just like what the figure below shows. Directly setting the displacement BC at the inner bound is not OK because I don't want this contract to cause extra stress respond. Does any one know how to realize this? One of my thoughts is to derive the after-contract position (xe, ye) of any point (x, y) to get the displacement field u(x, y) = (xe, ye) - (x, y). Then we can get the strain tensor εij = 0.5 * (∂ui/∂xj + ∂uj/∂xi) to construct an eigen strain material to realize the contract. Is this approach correct?

Firstly, whatever you do, make sure you solve this using RZ coordinates in MOOSE.
Secondly, i don't understand how you can deform the annulus and maintain stress=0.  The only stress=0 solution is when the displacement is zero (except for rigid-body movement).  Generally, when displacement!=0 then stress!=0.  i think i'm fundamentally misunderstanding something here.  Can you explain further?  Eg, do you also have temperature?

My understanding is that if we can give the ring an eigen strain that make it contract "uniformly", it may maintain stress = 0, just like a uniform thermal expansion process.  More specifically, if we can guarantee that the relative position of each point in the ring is not changed during the contract process (r1/r2 = r3/r4 in the figure), the stress may not be generated. Is this a wrong idea?

I think i don't have enough imagination to understand at the moment.  Where does this eigenstrain come from?  In your thermal expansion example, the eigenstrain comes from a temperature change, so while the stress=0, some other property (the temperature) has changed, which causes the displacement.  So, in your example, what's the other property that's going to change and cause displacement != 0.  Clearly, the displacement will depend on that property.  (For instance, if it were temperature and your annulus had anisotropic or heterogeneous thermal-expansion properties, then the displacement could be quite complicated compared with the isotropic, homogeneous case.)

Maybe what I said before is ambiguous ... In fact, my aim is just to find a way to change the geometry condition of the domain with time. More specifically, the user can specify the inner radius varying with time Rin(t) and the geometry will be changed with time in the simulation depending on Rin(t) while the outer radius is not changed. Since it is a pure geometry effect, I don't want this change to generate stress respond.
I think a possible way to realize this function is to create a NEW eigen strain for the material so that the annulus will deform as what Rin(t) describes with no stress respond. But how the annulus deforms with no stress respond?  my thought is that if the deformation is "uniform", the extra stress may not be generated, just like the uniform thermal expansion process. the "uniform" here means the relative position of each point in the ring is not changed during the contract process (r1/r2 = r3/r4 in the figure). So based on this geometry relation, we can get the displacement field u(x,y,Rin(t)), then we can get the eigen strain tensor εij = 0.5 * (∂ui/∂xj + ∂uj/∂xi), based on which the new eigen strain object (e.g., ComputeContractEigenStrain) will be developed. The inputs of the eigen strain object are Rin(t) and Rout. Do you think this approach is reasonable?

I might be understanding your question.  Is this true: you know that in real life, the deformation you describe will result in stress!=0, but you want to trick MOOSE so that it thinks stress=0 ?   If so, then i think just create your EigenStrain as you describe above.
That is exactly what I meant. Thank you!

The weak form in the READEME as follows:
and could you tell me why it is not necessary to define eps and deps in the \projects\moose\modules\phase_field\examples\anisotropic_interfaces\ad_snow.i ？
Let me rephrase the question, how do I modify the formulas for eps and deps in that example (e.g. change the isotropic factor from 4 to 2)

eps and deps are material properties, so you may modify them there.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Materials/
If you just want to add a factor you could just use an ADParsedMaterial for that
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ParsedMaterial.html

eps and deps are material properties, so you may modify them there. https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Materials/ If you just want to add a factor you could just use an ADParsedMaterial for that https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ParsedMaterial.html OK,I got you,I find that in materials/ADInterfaceOrientationMaterial.C,thank you so much!
